message.content:
cs.CL, cs.LG, cs.AI, cs.IR, cs.DS

This paper proposes a new kernel-based co-occurrence measure for sparse linguistic expressions, which is relevant to natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning (ML). Therefore, the most likely category is cs.CL (Computation and Language). The paper also introduces a new measure derived from the Hilbert-Schmidt independence criterion (HSIC), which is a statistical independence measure used in ML. This suggests that the paper could also be relevant to categories such as cs.LG (Machine Learning), cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence), and cs.IR (Information Retrieval). Finally, the paper discusses the empirical results of using the proposed measure in a dialogue response selection task, which involves data processing and analysis, indicating that it could also be relevant to cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms).
